ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the current state of the science of science communication literature!

I learned about different theories of science communication, particularly why science communication breaks down and why issues become polarized. I learned the relative merits of these approaches. Additionally, and more than most classes, I developed skills in critically comparing competing hypotheses and whether the methods of studies support the inferences being drawn. Also learned a lot of interesting information about real world issues like the controversies surrounding HPV, global warming, and evolution.
Critical thinking and analysis of how we think and talk about science in society.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought the day that the producers came to visit was super cool, but I think perhaps it could've been organized a bit differently? It felt a bit unstructured, and I think many people didn't get to talk to them much. Like if you could gather people's questions for them beforehand or something, that might increase engagement with them!
I enjoyed the professor's lecturing style. I found class discussion to be weak though, I'd have preferred just to listen to professor speak honestly

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I've already recommended the course to many of my friends!

I would recommend this course if you're interested in science communication, but beware that it is a law school seminar. If, like me, you get frustrated when people talk over each other and you aren't very assertive in seminars, you may have a difficult time in this class. Otherwise, it's an interesting introduction to the identity protective cognition thesis and Kahan's other work.
Definitely take this class if you're interested in understanding how science communication works in different setting and with different people.
